title: What happens to the momentum when two things collide and come to a rest? Where does the momentum go? - Quora

response.answer_text: One of the “prime directives” in our universe is conservation of momentum, due to one of several symmetries (Noether’s Theorem). When you stop at a traffic light, most assume momentum gets “absorbed” as heat in the brakes … but that is wrong; a car’s momentum transfers to the earth, which then spins into a slightly different direction. If two objects collide, they can bounce back or stop with a thud … in both cases, momentum is exactly conserved.

In a pure two body collision two objects may come to rest only if the initial total momentum was equal zero. This is the situation of the particles colliders as this configuration allows to use all the kinetic energy for creation of new particles. In every day life it is not always easy to isolate completely two objects from their environment in order to verify this momentum conservation law. Conservation Laws
